Ed, from the stack what is occuring is that the .dll required for SWT isn't 
being found.  How is SWT visible to the Java project you're editing the class 
in.  It should either be a plugin project that has org.eclipse.ui as a 
dependent plugin (or otherwise can see org.eclipse.swt project), or a regular 
Java project that has the Library SWT_CONTAINER in its build path (from the 
Add Library button on the library tab on the Java build path).  The kind of 
error you're seeing sometimes occurs if people add the swt.jar by hand into 
their build path which although this is OK for compilation purposes isn't 
enough information for the VE to be able to locate the .dll that it has to put 
into the -Dlibrary.path for the target JVM it starts.  
The best way to get a non PDE project configured correctly for the VE and SWT 
is to use the New Visual Class wizard and select that you want to create an 
SWT class in which case it gets automagically configured for you with the 
library correctly

Ed - Rich just noticed that you're running a 1.6 early adopter JVM.  We 
haven't really tested on 1.6.  If you use a 1.4 target does this fix things ?

Is the SWT container points to the right .jars?
can you attache the .classpath file from that project

Please reOpen if you can provide instructions of how to reCreate on the latest
driver.

We are cleaning these 1.1 defects in preperation for GA.
The SWT Container should point to the proper swt.jar and dll directory; you can
check these from the project's Properties->BuildPath->Libraries tab.  If you
open up the swt.jar you should see the native library path contribution.

I'm still getting this in VE-SDK-1.1.
To reproduce, do File > New Project, select Plug-in Project.
Enter a project name, click Next.
Click Yes to create a Rich Client application. Click Next
Select RCP Mail template. Click Finish.
Find NavigationView.java, right click, select Open With > Visual Editor.
This is where all the errors appear.

I've tried setting the project's JRE to 1.5.0_2 or 1.4.2_06 and it didn't help.

If I right click on the project, select Properties, Java Build Path, Libraries
tab, I can see org.eclipse.ui_3.1.0.jar, org.eclipse.swt_3.1.0.jar,
org.eclipse.swt.win32.win32.x86_3.1.0.jar and some others. If I expand the swt
jars, I see "Native library location: (None) - non modifiable".

Can not reCreate this using 1.4/1.5 JREs.

The reason for the trace above is that the target VM for the editor did not have
access to the SWT library; either because the lib. path is wrong, or that VE did
not extract/cache the SWT libraries on your machine (the SWT libraries are
contributed/extracted and cached by the VE target VM launcher via the
SWTConfigurationContributor helper).  

The extracted/cached SWT library path (in a 3.1 environment) is set to 

-Djava.library.path=<workspace>/.metadata/.plugins/org.eclipse.ve.java.core/.cache/.libCache/<someNumber>/


Can you check if the SWT libraries were extracted on your machine, and can you
tell (from the command line properties of the javaw.exe process of the target
VM) if the library path is set correctly set?

I see this directory:

which has these files:

If a WorkBench Part's parent argumet name collide with an instance variable
name, VE will get confused.


public Composite parent;

createPartControl(Composite parent)
*** Bug 105461 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Codegen parsing was not modelling the argument 'parent' because it already saw
one as a field. Reusing of instance variables is common and this has been fixed.
Releasing class JFaceMethodVisitor, BeanPartDecleration. Similar to bug 104803.
